https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The practice of protecting and managing sites and landscapes which have value for their geology or geomorphology. The identification (cf. geoheritage) and conservation of these geological sites is through government agencies and local geological societies. The designation of these sites is done through an analysis of the site, and the production of proper management infrastructure. The principles of geoconservation are to create a means of protection for the sites and assess their value to the geological and wider community. Typically the conservation of geodiversity at a site or within a landscape takes place alongside that of biodiversity.
Tourism that sustains or enhances the distinctive geographical character of a place — its environment, heritage, aesthetics, culture, and the well-being of its residents​.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Land-use and environmental planning involves the regulation and commitment of land-use, as to how the landscape is used (whether for food production, forestry, nature conservation, water storage, urban development, mining, etc.), to ensure the most efficient, effective and beneficial management and utilization of resources, and to provide optimal environmental and social outcomes.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Land-use and environmental planning involves the regulation and commitment of land-use, as to how the landscape is used (whether for food production, forestry, nature conservation, water storage, urban development, mining, etc.), to ensure the most efficient, effective and beneficial management and utilization of resources, and to provide optimal environmental and social outcomes.
